content:
Fractures of the upper and lower extremities vary by mechanism, associated neurovascular risks, and management requirements.  This article reviews the anatomy of the upper and lower extremities, general principles of fracture assessment and management, and the unique features of different fracture types.

Upper extremity anatomy

Major vascular structures



Axillary, brachial, radial, and ulnar arteries (

figure 1
).

Major nerves



  • Brachial plexus (
    figure 2
    ):  A network of nerves originating from the spinal cord (C5-T1) that provides motor and sensory innervation to the shoulder, arm, and hand.  Divides into 5 major peripheral nerves:  the axillary, musculocutaneous, radial, median, and ulnar nerves.
  • Axillary nerve (
    figure 3
    ):  Innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles, allowing shoulder abduction and external rotation.  Provides sensation to the skin over the lateral shoulder (
    figure 4
    ).
  • Musculocutaneous nerve (
    figure 5
    ):  Controls elbow flexion by innervating the biceps brachii, brachialis, and coracobrachialis muscles.  Provides sensation to the lateral forearm (
    figure 6
    ).
  • Radial nerve (
    figure 7
    ):  Controls extension of the elbow (triceps), wrist, and fingers, and assists in forearm supination.  Provides sensation to the posterior arm, forearm, and back of the hand, including the thumb, index, and middle fingers (
    figure 8
    ).
  • Median nerve (
    figure 9
    ):  Controls most of the muscles responsible for flexing the wrist and fingers (flexor muscles), as well as thumb opposition (thenar muscles).  Supplies sensation to the palmar side of the thumb, index, middle finger, and lateral half of the ring finger (
    figure 10
    ).
  • Ulnar nerve (
    figure 11
    ):  Innervates muscles that control fine movements in the hand (intrinsic hand muscles), as well as wrist and finger flexion on the ulnar side.  Provides sensation to the palmar and dorsal surfaces of the little finger and medial half of the ring finger (
    figure 12
    ).

Skeletal/muscular structures



Bony structures in the arm include the humerus, radius, and ulna.  Major muscles include the biceps (

figure 13
), triceps (
figure 14
), forearm flexors, and extensors.

Lower extremity anatomy

Major vascular structures



Femoral, popliteal, tibial, and dorsalis pedis arteries (

figure 15
).

Major nervous structures



  • Femoral nerve (
    figure 16
    ):  Innervates the muscles of the anterior thigh, including the quadriceps femoris (extends the knee joint).  Supplies sensation to the anterior thigh and medial leg.
  • Sciatic nerve (
    figure 17
    ):  Splits into the tibial and common fibular (peroneal) nerves, aids in knee flexion.  Supplies sensation to the posterior thigh, posterior leg, and most of the foot.
  • Deep peroneal nerve (
    figure 18
    ):  Innervates the muscles of the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, including the tibialis anterior and peroneal muscles (which dorsiflex the ankle and extend the toes).  Supplies sensation to the anterolateral leg and dorsum of the foot.
  • Tibial nerve (
    figure 19
    ):  Innervates the posterior compartment of the leg, including the gastrocnemius, soleus, and muscles of the foot.  Provides sensation to the sole of the foot and the posterior calf.

Skeletal/muscular structures



Bony structures in the lower extremity include the femur, tibia, fibula, and patella.  Major muscles in the lower extremity include the following (

figure 20
):



  • Quadriceps muscles (rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, vastus intermedius)
  • Hamstrings (biceps femoris, semitendinosus, semimembranosus)
  • Calf muscles (gastrocnemius, soleus, tibialis anterior and posterior, fibularis longus and brevis, flexor and extensor digitorum longus, flexor and extensor hallucis longus)

General fracture evaluation and management

History and clinical presentation



Patients with fractures typically present with localized pain, swelling, deformity, and an inability to move the affected limb.  In cases of displaced fractures, the limb may appear shortened, angulated, or rotated.  The mechanism of injury is important to consider because certain mechanisms are associated with specific injury patterns.  For example, a patient who falls on an outstretched hand is at risk of multiple injuries, including distal radius fracture (eg, Colles fracture), ulnar styloid fracture, scaphoid fracture, and a variety of other injuries to the elbow and shoulder (

figure 21
).

Physical examination



Inspection of the affected limb should include evaluating for deformity, swelling, bruising, and an assessment of neurovascular status (eg, checking distal pulses, capillary refill, sensory and motor function).  The forces that cause a bone fracture can also affect adjacent joints (eg, dislocations, ligament damage).  This underscores the importance of thoroughly examining the joints above and below the fracture.  For example, a Galeazzi fractureâ€”a distal radius fracture with associated dislocation of the distal radioulnar jointâ€”demonstrates how a fracture in one bone can disrupt the stability of a nearby joint.



Every fracture should be evaluated to determine whether it is closed or open.



  • Closed fractures:  Skin remains intact with no direct communication between the fracture site and the external environment.
  • Open fractures:  A disruption of both the bone and the overlying soft tissue causes a breach in the skin exposing the bone fragments to the external environment.


Open fractures are associated with a higher risk of complications, such as osteomyelitis and nonunion, and necessitate prompt management, including antibiotic prophylaxis and urgent irrigation and debridement (eg, usually within hours).

Evaluation



Radiographic imaging is essential for evaluating the fracture's location, type, and extent.  X-rays in at least 2 views (eg, anteroposterior and lateral) are typically sufficient, but CT scans or MRI may be necessary for complex fractures or those involving joints (eg, tibial plateau fractures).

Management



  • Reduction:  Any displaced fractures should be reduced (ie, realigned) immediately as close as possible to normal anatomical position.  This is particularly important in cases of neurovascular compromise (eg, absent pulses) as realignment may restore function.  Fractures that are not reduced appropriately or in a timely manner are at greater risk of complications (eg, neurovascular injury).
  • Splinting:  Following fracture reduction (if indicated), a splint should be applied to immobilize the bone, alleviate pain, and prevent further injury.  Splints are typically used in the acute phase because they allow for swelling, whereas a rigid, circumferential cast could constrict the limb as swelling increases, potentially leading to increased pain or even compartment syndrome.
  • Surgical intervention:  Typically required when the fracture is open or there is significant displacement, instability, or involvement of joints.  The timing of surgery depends on the location and specific characteristics of the fracture.

Upper extremity fractures



The main upper extremity fractures discussed in this article include:



  • Clavicle fractures
  • Humerus fractures
  • Elbow/forearm fractures

Clavicle fracture

Pathogenesis



Typically occurs after a fall.  The clavicle is divided into 3 segments:  distal third, mid-shaft, and proximal third.  The majority of fractures occur in the mid-shaft (69%), followed by the distal third (28%).  Fractures of the proximal third are rare and are associated with other serious head, neck, or thoracic injuries (in ~90% of cases).

Clinical presentation



Shoulder movement often exacerbates the pain; swelling, bruising, crepitus, and focal tenderness may also be present.

Diagnosis



Plain radiographs confirm the fracture and assess displacement (

image 1
).

Management



Nondisplaced clavicle fractures are generally managed with immobilization, using a sling (or figure-of-eight bandage) to restrict motion to <30 degrees of abduction, extension, and forward flexion.  Immobilization should continue until bony union occurs (typically 3-6 weeks in children and 6-12 weeks in adults).  Displaced fractures may require surgery.

Special considerations



  • Distal clavicle fractures have a greater incidence of nonunion because the proximal fragment is pulled in the superomedial direction by the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles while the weight of the arm and contraction of the deltoid muscle pulls the distal fragment in the inferolateral (ie, opposite) direction (
    figure 22
    ).
  • Subclavian vessels and brachial plexus can be injured in patients with displaced clavicle fractures.

Humerus fractures

Proximal humerus fracture



  • Pathogenesis:  Commonly occur in falls; risk factors include age >65 and osteoporosis.  They often occur as isolated injuries but may also be associated with glenohumeral dislocation.
  • Clinical presentation:  Proximal arm pain, swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, or guarding after a fall.  Pain with attempted range of motion at the shoulder may be severe and often limits examination.
  • Diagnosis:  Plain radiographs to assess fracture pattern and displacement and to ensure the humeral head is not dislocated.
  • Management:  Uncomplicated, nondisplaced fractures are usually managed nonoperatively with immobilization and early rehabilitation.  Complex, displaced, or angulated fractures or fractures with concurrent dislocation of the humeral head may need surgical intervention and warrant orthopedic consultation.
  • Special considerations:
    • Avascular necrosis of the humeral head can occur following fractures of the humeral neck, which disrupt the retrograde blood flow from the anterior and posterior circumflex humeral arteries.  These arteries, which are branches of the axillary artery, form an anastomosis around the neck of the humerus, supplying blood to the proximal humerus and glenohumeral joint (
      figure 23
      ).
    • Shoulder dislocations can occur with a proximal humerus fracture or in isolation (
      figure 24
      ).  When they occur in isolation, the joint should be reduced immediately as prolonged dislocation can compromise axillary nerve function (tested via sensation over the lateral shoulder) (
      figure 25
      ).  A concomitant proximal humerus fracture is generally considered a contraindication to closed reduction of a shoulder dislocation because the force applied during the reduction attempt may cause further displacement of the fracture.  Therefore, dislocations associated with humeral neck fractures typically undergo open surgical repair rather than closed reduction in the emergency department.

Midshaft humerus fracture



  • Pathogenesis:  Generally seen following a direct blow to the arm, a fall, an automobile injury, or a crushing injury.
  • Clinical presentation:  Arm pain, tenderness, and swelling with decreased range of motion at the elbow and shoulder.  Deformity or angulation of the arm may be visible.
  • Diagnosis:  Plain radiographs to assess fracture pattern and displacement.
  • Management:  Most cases of isolated diaphyseal (midshaft) humeral fracture can be treated nonsurgically (eg, closed reduction followed by arm immobilization with a coaptation or sugar-tong splint); open reduction and surgical exploration are indicated with open fractures, significant displacement (eg, arm shortening, as in this patient), neurovascular compromise (eg, asymmetric radial pulses, as in this patient), polytrauma, and pathologic fractures.
  • Special considerations:  The deep brachial (profunda brachii) artery and radial nerve (
    figure 26
    ) run together along the posterior aspect of the humerus.  Midshaft fractures of the humerus risk injury to these structures.

Elbow/forearm fractures

Radial head fracture



  • Pathogenesis:  Often occurs from a fall on an outstretched hand.
  • Clinical presentation:  Pain and tenderness over the lateral elbow pain.  Elbow motion may be limited, particularly supination.
  • Diagnosis:  Plain radiographs of the elbow should be obtained, but radial head fractures are often difficult to detect on initial radiographs.  A positive sail sign (elevation of the anterior or posterior fat pad; a sign of joint effusion or hemarthrosis) on a lateral X-ray suggests a fracture even if the fracture itself is not immediately apparent.
  • Management:  A brief period of immobilization (24-48 hours) is indicated for nondisplaced fractures.  Early mobilization is important for achieving optimal recovery.  Displaced fractures or fractures with significant joint involvement may require surgical intervention.
  • Special considerations:
    • A high index of suspicion needs to be maintained to avoid missing the diagnosis of radial head fracture.
    • Neurovascular injuries are uncommon with isolated fractures.

Distal radius fracture (Colles fracture):



  • Pathogenesis:  Commonly occurs after falling on an outstretched hand, particularly in athletes (high-impact falls) or elderly patients with osteoporosis (low-impact falls).
  • Clinical presentation:  Characteristic manifestations include pain, swelling, and dinner fork deformity (
    figure 27
    ) of the wrist.
  • Diagnosis:  Pain radiographs to assess fracture pattern and displacement.
  • Management:  Closed reduction and cast immobilization for most cases.  Surgical intervention may be required for complex fractures (eg, intraarticular fracture) or significant displacement.
  • Special considerations:
    • Dorsal displacement of the radius (as occurs in Colles fracture) can result in compression of the median nerve, which enters the wrist through the carpal tunnel (
      figure 28
      ) and provides sensation to the lateral 3Â½ digits and motor innervation to the thenar muscles (eg, opponens pollicis, abductor pollicis brevis).  Compression results in acute carpal tunnel syndrome symptoms, including paresthesia of the affected digits and impaired thumb abduction by abductor pollicis brevis.
    • If compression occurs proximal to the tunnel, the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve may be affected, leading to decreased sensation over the anterolateral hand.

Scaphoid fracture



  • Pathogenesis:  Frequently results from a fall on an outstretched hand that causes direct axial compression or hyperextension of the wrist.
  • Clinical presentation:  Persistent wrist pain and tenderness in the anatomic snuffboxâ€”a shallow, triangular depression at the dorsoradial wrist bounded medially by the tendon of the extensor pollicis longus and laterally by the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis (
    figure 29
    ).
  • Diagnosis:  X-ray at the time of injury has low sensitivity for scaphoid fracture.  Therefore, if initial x-rays are negative, CT scan or MRI of the wrist is recommended to confirm the fracture.  As an alternative, the wrist can be immobilized briefly in a thumb spica splint, followed by repeat imaging in 7-10 days.  Either approach can be considered; repeat x-ray is associated with lower up-front costs, whereas MRI may allow for earlier return to normal activity.
  • Management:  Patients with a nondisplaced fracture (
    image 2
    ) who do not meet surgical indications should be placed in a short arm thumb spica cast; serial x-rays should be done in 2-week intervals to monitor healing.  The duration of immobilization depends on the fracture site.  Some cases may require surgery (eg, displaced fracture, scapholunate dissociation).
  • Special considerations:  Scaphoid fractures are most commonly complicated by nonunion and avascular necrosis.  The arterial blood supply to the scaphoid enters in the distal pole and travels to the proximal pole (
    figure 30
    ).  Scaphoid fractures (particularly at the waist and proximal end of the scaphoid) can compromise the blood supply, causing avascular necrosis and increasing the risk of nonunion (up to 10% of cases).

Lower extremity fractures



The main lower extremity fractures discussed in this article include:



  • Hip fractures
  • Midshaft femur fractures
  • Tibia fractures
  • Jones fracture (proximal fifth metatarsal fracture)
  • Calcaneal fracture
  • Stress fracture

Hip fractures

Pathogenesis



Hip fractures are classified as either intracapsular (femoral head and neck) or extracapsular (intertrochanteric, subtrochanteric).



  • Intracapsular:  Often occurs due to low-energy trauma, particularly in older adults with osteoporosis.  In younger individuals, fractures typically result from axial loading during major trauma (eg, motor vehicle collision).
  • Extracapsular:  Most commonly due to falls in older adults but can also result from high-energy trauma (eg, motor vehicle collision, falls from significant heights).

Clinical presentation 



  • Intracapsular (
    figure 31
    ):  Typically presents with severe pain in the groin and hip and a shortened, externally rotated leg.  Significant ecchymoses are typically absent.
  • Extracapsular:  Presents with severe pain in groin and hip.  Leg may be shortened but ecchymoses are more common.

Diagnosis



Plain radiographs (

image 3
) are typically adequate.  Occult hip fractures can occur that require CT or MRI for definitive diagnosis.

Management



Prompt surgical repair (eg, total hip arthroplasty, intramedullary nail) should be performed in the vast majority of patients.  In older adults, early surgical intervention (eg, within 24 hr) is associated with decreased mortality.  Patients who have acutely unstable medical conditions (eg, active infection, unstable angina) may have surgical repair delayed briefly, but delays >72 hours are associated with increased risk of complications.  Nonoperative management is associated with significantly higher mortality (eg, 4-fold increase at 1 year) and is typically reserved for patients who were nonambulatory prior to the fracture or who have severe dementia, end-stage terminal illness, or major comorbidities that cannot be stabilized.  Younger patients with fractures due to high-energy trauma should be surgically repaired as soon as possible.

Special considerations: 



  • Intracapsular fractures:  Place the femoral head at risk for osteonecrosis if its blood supply is disrupted.  The blood supply to the femoral head derives mainly from the ascending cervical and retinacular branches of the medial circumflex femoral artery (
    figure 32
    ).  These vessels are especially vulnerable to damage from fractures of the femoral neck due to their close association with it.
  • Extracapsular fractures:  Associated with lower risk of avascular necrosis but typically are more displaced due to the action of the iliopsoas muscle (pulls on the lesser trochanter) and the major external rotator and abductor muscles (which pull on the greater trochanter).


Hip fractures are described in more detail in a separate article.

Midshaft femur fractures

Pathogenesis



Commonly caused by high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle collisions, falls from significant height, or direct blunt force trauma (eg, contact sports, industrial accidents).

Clinical presentation



Severe pain localized to the midshaft of the femur, accompanied by bruising, swelling, and tenderness over the fracture site.  Deformity and shortening of the affected leg may be present if the fracture is displaced.  Signs of shock may be present, as the femur has a rich vascular supply, and a fracture can result in significant hemorrhage.

Diagnosis



Plain radiographs are typically adequate to make the diagnosis.

Management



Temporary immobilization through traction or a splint is often applied to minimize pain and prevent further injury.  Definitive treatment usually involves surgical intervention (eg, intramedullary nailing, open reduction and internal fixation).  Nonoperative treatment is reserved for nondisplaced fractures in select patients (eg, medically unstable).

Special considerations



  • The femoral artery and major veins run in close proximity to the femur, and traumatic injury to these vessels can result in significant blood loss and hemorrhagic shock.
  • Femur fractures can also cause fat embolism syndrome (see article on the topic); patients with multiple long bone fractures are at greatest risk.
  • Compartment syndrome can occur in the thigh but is rare.

Tibia fractures



  • Pathogenesis:  Typically result from high-energy trauma, falls, or sports injuries.
  • Clinical presentation:  Severe pain in the leg, swelling, deformity, inability to bear weight.
  • Diagnosis:  Plain radiographs are typically adequate.  Fractures involving the proximal tibia (eg, tibial plateau (
    image 4
    ) often require a CT to determine the extent of the fracture.
  • Management:  Nonoperative treatment (eg, casting) may be appropriate for stable, nondisplaced fractures.  Proximal tibial fractures should be splinted with the knee in full extension.  Displaced, unstable fractures require operative management (eg, intramedullary nail).
  • Special considerations:  Patients with tibia fractures from high-energy mechanisms are at significant risk of compartment syndrome.  Patients with proximal fractures often have concomitant injuries to ligaments of the knee.

Ankle fracture (vs ankle sprain)



  • Pathogenesis:  Sprains and fractures and most often due to inversion of a plantar-flexed foot.  The most common ankle sprains involve only the anterior talofibular ligament (
    figure 33
    ); the lateral ankle ligaments are weaker and are injured more often than the medial ligaments.  Fractures/joint dislocations may occur with stronger forces, which can injure multiple ligaments, leading to significant joint instability with possible nerve injury.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Ankle sprain:  Moderate pain, swelling, tenderness, mild to moderate difficulty bearing weight.
    • Ankle fracture:  Severe pain, swelling, bruising, difficulty bearing weight, bony point tenderness.
  • Diagnosis:  The Ottawa ankle rules (
    figure 34
    ) were developed to determine which patients require imaging to rule out an ankle fracture.  These rules have high sensitivity (up to 99%) for detecting fracture and can help reduce the number of unnecessary radiographs.  Plain radiographs of the ankle are indicated in patients with pain in the area of the malleolus (lateral or medial) in association with either
    • (1) point tenderness over the posterior margin or tip of the malleolus or
    • (2) inability to bear weight after the injury and for 4 steps during medical evaluation (eg, inability to walk to the examination room).
  • Management:
    • Ankle sprain:  Initial management should include standard RICE measures (rest, ice, compression, elevation).  In higher-grade sprains (eg, grade II/III-partial/complete tear of the ankle ligaments), which manifest with significant swelling, ecchymosis, or joint instability, functional braces (eg, air stirrup brace) are recommended.
    • Ankle fracture:  Nonoperative treatment (eg, cast immobilization) for stable fractures or operative treatment for unstable or displaced fractures.

Jones fracture (proximal fifth metatarsal fracture)



  • Pathogenesis:  Typically due to a twisting force on the foot with the forefoot planted.  Other causes include a direct blow to the lateral foot or a high-impact fall.
  • Clinical presentation:  Pain in the lateral midfoot (anterior to the ankle) associated with tenderness at the base of the fifth metatarsal (
    figure 35
    ) or inability to bear weight on the foot.
  • Diagnosis:  Plain radiographs showing transverse fracture of the fifth metatarsal at the metadiaphyseal junction are typically adequate to diagnose Jones fracture (
    image 5
    ).
  • Management:  Initial management of a nondisplaced fracture includes nonâ€“weight-bearing for the first 6-8 weeks following injury.  Early surgical intervention may be indicated in those with significantly displaced fractures or in highly active individuals (eg, competitive athletes) due to the higher rate of nonunion and refracture in this population.
  • Special considerations:  Jones fractures have a high rate of nonunion due to the limited blood supply of the affected bone.

Calcaneal fracture



  • Pathogenesis:  Typically occurs from a high-energy mechanism.  Axial loading of the foot following a fall from a height is the most common cause of significant calcanus fractures.
  • Clinical presentation:  Severe pain in the heel and tenderness over the heel with difficulty bearing weight is common.  Swelling, bruising, and deformity of the heel may also be present.
  • Diagnosis:  Plain radiographs (
    image 6
    ) are the initial imaging studies, but patients with negative radiographs who have a suspicious history or physical examination for fracture should undergo CT scan.  A CT is also typically indicated to determine the extent of a fracture and to plan operative repair.
  • Management:  Nonoperative treatment (eg, cast immobilization, nonâ€“weight-bearing) is typically adequate for nondisplaced fractures.  Operative treatment is indicated for displaced or comminuted fractures.
  • Special considerations:  There is a high incidence of concomitant thoracolumbar spine (10%-15% of patients) fractures in patients with calcaneus fractures.  Therefore, it is important to perform a thorough examination of the spine and consider imaging to evaluate for potential fractures in these patients.

Stress fracture



  • Pathogenesis:  Typically results from repetitive, low-energy forces over time rather than a single traumatic event.  A common injury in athletes, especially runners, and nonathletes (eg, military recruits, dancers) who suddenly increase their exercise (eg, intensity, time, distance).  Biomechanical (eg, pes planus) and metabolic factors (eg, functional hypothalamic amenorrhea, decreased bone mineral density) increase the risk.
  • Clinical presentation:  Typical findings include subacute, activity-related pain, which may progress to rest pain, and point tenderness over the fracture (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ).
  • Diagnosis:  Initial plain x-rays have low sensitivity and are often negative during the first few weeks.  In many cases, if the initial x-ray is negative, patients may be managed empirically based on clinical findings.  However, if a definitive diagnosis is needed (eg, high-risk fracture site), MRI is indicated because it can detect bone marrow edema and early-stage stress fractures not visible on x-ray.
  • Management:  Nonoperative management (eg, activity modification/restriction and analgesics, risk factor reduction, and gradual resumption of activity when pain free) is the mainstay for most stress fractures.  In rare cases where nonoperative treatment fails, or the stress fracture becomes displaced or severe, surgical intervention may be indicated.
  • Special considerations:  Stress fractures at low risk for complications include fractures of the second and third metatarsal shafts, fibula, proximal humerus or humeral shaft, ribs, sacrum, and pubic rami.  Stress fractures at increased risk of complications (eg, displacement, fracture propagation) include fractures of the femoral head, femoral neck, tibia, and multiple sites at ankle and foot (eg, medial malleolus, talus, tarsal navicular, proximal fifth and fourth metatarsals).  High-risk fractures require more aggressive interventions (eg, orthopedic referral, nonâ€“weight-bearing status, surgical intervention).

Complications



  • Arterial injury:  Fractures, particularly those involving long bones or near major joints, can cause direct damage to adjacent arteries, resulting in hemorrhage, ischemia, or limb-threatening arterial occlusion.
  • Nerve injury:  Nerve injury may occur from direct mechanical injury, compression by swelling or displaced bone fragments, or from traction on the nerve during limb manipulation.  Depending on the nerve involved, patients may experience sensory deficits, motor impairment, or complete paralysis.
  • Compartment syndrome:  Occurs when increased pressure within a closed muscle compartment compromises microcirculation, leading to muscle ischemia and potential necrosis.  It most commonly affects the lower leg and forearm and demands urgent surgical decompression (fasciotomy) to prevent permanent functional loss.
  • Deep vein thrombosis:  Immobilization, trauma, and surgery following fractures increase the risk of venous thromboembolism particularly in the lower extremities.  Thromboprophylaxis should be administered in at-risk patients.
  • Fat embolism syndrome:  Fat embolism syndrome occurs when fat globules released from the bone marrow enter the circulation, often following fractures of long bones or the pelvis.  Symptoms typically present within 24-72 hours and include respiratory distress, neurological deficits, and a characteristic petechial rash, requiring prompt supportive care and sometimes mechanical ventilation.
  • Osteomyelitis:  Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone, commonly resulting from open fractures.  It is characterized by localized pain, swelling, fever, and, in severe cases, sepsis; management involves long-term antibiotics and (potentially) surgical debridement to prevent chronic infection or bone necrosis.
  • Nonunion:  Nonunion refers to the failure of a fracture to heal within an expected time frame, typically due to factors such as inadequate stabilization, infection, or poor biological healing conditions.  This complication often necessitates surgical intervention, including bone grafting or revision of fixation, to promote healing and restore function.

Summary



This conceptual framework emphasizes a systematic approach to evaluating and managing fractures by considering injury mechanisms, anatomical locations, and potential complications.  Understanding specific fracture patterns helps guide diagnosis, while careful neurovascular assessment ensures prompt identification of risks (eg, neurovascular injury).  Management strategiesâ€”realignment, immobilization, and surgical interventionâ€”are tailored to the fracture's characteristics.  Despite the diversity of fracture types, the core principles of fracture care remain central to effective treatment across both upper and lower extremity injuries.
